item.content:encoded: Top of WSJ today. Compelling read: ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs 80-year run has been rooted in 2 major US initiatives: Bretton Woods, which enshrined free trade and low tariffs. And NATO, which won the Cold War. Both of these legacies are being undone with stunning speed by President Trump.‚Äù

item.content:encoded: Can‚Äôt disagree w/ Klein‚Äôs idea that Ds should make gov‚Äôt work better‚Äîeg, relax environmental restraints so that high-speed rail is deployed faster. But this can‚Äôt be the centerpiece of a political campaign to combat Trumpism. Economic justice is more compelling than ‚Äúabundance.‚Äù
item.author: Hal Singer

item.content:encoded: Expeditor's is an interesting one. Very little reinvestment, no acqusitions. Wild bullwhip in earnings and cash flow but still ends up with 68% cash on cash returns L10Yr Returns ~all capital to shareholders. FDSO (35%), EPS +260% '10 - '24 Trades for 20.8x P / NTM E $EXPD

item.content:encoded: Tho @TheEconomist correctly pushes back on Vance‚Äôs silly theory that immigrants drive housing inflation, the neoliberal rag overlooks the role of common algorithmic pricing or roll-ups of properties in the same neighborhood. Never blame the landlords (or any firm setting prices)!
item.author: Hal Singer

item.content:encoded: TSMC, for all its might, is not the fastest-growing automotive foundry. GloFo has outgrown TSMC in 3 of last 4 years in auto and will likely repeat in CY25. Design-wins in ADAS, sensor and MCU, share gains with auto grade 22FDX and increased silicon content drove GloFo's growth.
item.author: Sravan Kundojjala

item.content:encoded:
Wow! This is just from one lab.
The ROI on government grants is astronomical, especially when you consider that most of the value to society from basic science goes way beyond stock market valuations.
Defunding one America's greatest successes is insanely bad policy.
